metadata.title: Benzoic acid-assisted substrate-free synthesis of ultrathin nanosheets assembled two-dimensional porous Co3O4 thin sheets with 3D hierarchical micro-/nano-structures and enhanced performance as battery-type materials for supercapacitors

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Electrochimica Acta
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/e lectacta
Benzoic acid-assisted substrate-free synthesis of ultrathin nanosheets assembled two-dimensional porous Co3O4 thin sheets with 3D hierarchical micro-/nano-structures and enhanced performance as battery-type materials for supercapacitors
Jikui Zhu a, 1, Biao Huang a, 1, Chenglan Zhao a, Hong Xu a, Suna Wang b, Youpeng Chen c, Li Xie a, Lingyun Chen a, *
a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing, 400044, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, 252059, China c Faculty of Urban Construction and Environmental Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing, 400044, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 30 October 2018 Received in revised form 30 April 2019 Accepted 5 May 2019 Available online 9 May 2019
Keywords: Two-dimensional porous materials Co3O4 thin sheets Benzoic acid Supercapacitor Electrochemical energy storage
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: lychen@cqu.edu.cn (L. Chen). 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2019.05.019 0013-4686/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Two-dimensional (2D) porous materials have been proved to be meritorious for supercapacitors (SCs) due to unique properties of large surface area, superior intrinsic porosity and high electrical conductivity. In this work, we reported for the first synthesis of 2D porous Co3O4 thin sheets assembled by ultrathin nanosheets via direct hydrothermal decomposition of aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate in the presence of benzoic acid (BA) without any template or surfactant. High specific capacity (497, 598.5 and 399 C g 1 at 1.0 A g 1) and remarkable cycling stability (9.8, 6.3 and 13.1% loss over 8000 cycles at 10.0 A g 1) were achieved in a three-electrode system for the Co3O4 thin sheets at 200 C for 6, 12 and 24 h with different specific surface area of 69.96, 142.15 and 42.07m2 g 1, which can be attributed to the special structural feature of an open and porous surface layer and the synergistic effect of 2D and 3D structure that significantly facilitates fast electron transport, ion diffusion and intimate electrode/electrolyte contact. Furthermore, an assembled asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC, Co3O4 thin sheets//activated carbon (AC)) can reach a working output potential difference of 0e1.6 V with a maximum energy density of 22.49Wh$kg 1 at the power density of 800Wkg 1 with excellent cyclic stability (only 8.2% loss of its initial specific capacity value over 10000 cycles). The results show that our synthesis provides a new insight into the fabrication of 2D hierarchical porous Co3O4 thin sheets; in addition, the as-synthesized Co3O4 thin sheets have potential for various applications in SCs, electrochemical sensing, and lithium ion battery.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With ever-increasing demand for clean and renewable energy sources especially rapid development of portable electronic devices and hybrid electric vehicles as well as growing concerns for the environment, advanced and environmental friendly energy storage and conversion devices have stimulated intensive attention [1e3]. In the field of energy storage devices, supercapacitors (SCs) have recently become popular and have been extensively applied in
electric vehicles and portable electronic communication devices due to their high power density, faster charging/discharging rate and excellent cycling performance [4,5]. In general, electrode materials are the key to SCs and determine their main performances and applications. Up to date, the development of efficient, highperformance materials for SCs with large scale using simple and facile methods is essential to meet ever-increasing needs for electrical energy [6e8].
Transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been found to be a type of excellent candidates for SCs due to their excellent physical and chemical properties, as well as superior stability in electrochemical systems [9e11]. Among various TMOs, battery-type materials, such as Co3O4 [12], NiO [13], Co(OH)2 [14], Ni(OH)2 [15], Ni1-xCox (OH)2
composites [16e18] are able to store energy through dynamic redox reactions with the transmission of electrolyte ions, which leads to higher specific capacitance and energy density than traditional electric double layer capacitor (EDLC)-type and pseudocapacitive materials [19,20]. However, battery-type materials still suffer from small specific surface area, short cyclic life, and unsatisfactory rate capability. Recently, Co-based materials have received considerable interest because of low cost and more naturally abundant than noblemetal oxides (such as RuO2 and IrO2) and multi-oxidation states for charge transfer and reversible adsorption used as electrodematerials [21e23]. In particular, Co3O4 with typical spinel configuration exhibits higher theoretical specific capacitance (3650 F g 1), excellent reversibility, low price, and more abundant reserves, as well as well-defined electrochemical redox activity [24e26]. However, the application of Co3O4 as electrode materials for SCs is largely limited by its poor electrical conductivity which cannot fully utilize its theoretical capacity. To improve its conductivity, Co3O4 are either mixed with or compound with carbon and other conductive materials, such as carbon black, carbon nanotube, graphene, and polyaniline [27e29]. However, the use of other conductive component would decrease surface active sites and the surface area of Co3O4. As is known to all, the capacitive performances of electrodematerials could be varied as a function of the microstructure [30e33]. With the increase of dimensionality, abundant active sites are exposed in electrolyte for direct electron transfer processes, which effectively increases the reactive surfaces, and accordingly improves the specific capacity of electrode materials for SCs. It is established that the Co3O4 electrodes with layered morphologies, especially an ultrathin nanosheet structure, deliver high electrochemical performance and superior cycling stability [34e36]. And the justification for the usage of Co3O4 as electrode materials for SCs is their potential to attain high capacitance with low cost. Although various two-dimensional (2D) and 3D Co3O4 nanostructures have been reported, most of these procedures typically involve organic solvents, surfactants, complex manipulations, and equipment, leading to high costs of the product and often yielding impurities.
As a promising candidate for SCs electrode materials, 2D porous material have recently received significant attention owning to relatively large specific surface area with more abundant electroactive sites which can greatly promote the reaction kinetics, thereby being widely applied in many fields such as sensing, catalysis and electrochemical energy storage [37e39]. Although great efforts have been devoted to the synthesis of 2D porous transition metal oxides as battery-type electrode material for SCs, most synthesis process still require surfactants, templates, complicated synthesis steps and equipment, which result in high cost, the existence of by-products and unsatisfactory electrochemical performance. In recent years, we have been focused on the substrate-free facile synthesis of various 2D porous thin sheets of metal oxides/hydroxides and coordination complexes and their application for electrochemical energy storage [40e45]. Moreover, these 2D thin sheets can be simply prepared through facile hydrothermal methods. Meanwhile, the ultrathin nanosheets assembled 2D porous thin sheets with 3D hierarchical micro-/ nano-structures is quite similar to those of low or multilayer graphene and can serve as excellent 3D frameworks for direct fabrication of SCs with high pore volume and appropriate electrical conductivity.
As one of the most important organic acids, carboxylic acid can be divided into fatty acids and aromatic ones, or into monobasic acid, binary acid and polybasic acid. Among various carboxylic acid, acetic acid (CH3COOH) and oxalic acid (HOOC-COOH) have been used for direct or indirect synthesis of transition metal oxides as pH regulator or precursor coordination agent, which is attributed to
their weak acid, certain coordination ability and relatively stable coordination precursor with unique structures [46e48]. As one kind of monobasic weak acid with pKa of 4.20, benzoic acid (C6H5COOH, BA) is widely found in nature and can form many functional coordination complexes [49e52]. However, BA has never been reported for the synthesis of transition metals nanostructures in aqueous solution due to its slightly soluble in water.
We are interested in the construction of novel 2D porous nanostructures of transition metal oxides, coordination complexes, and carbon materials [53e63]. Herein, we demonstrated a facile synthesis of 2D porous Co3O4 thin sheets via one-step hydrothermal decomposition of aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2) in the presence of BA. The as-synthesized spinel Co3O4 thin sheets are assembled by 3D ultrathin nanoflake array and featured with larger surface active site ratio and enriched with Co3þ on the 2D nanostructure surface, leading to a high specific capacity of 598.5 C g 1 at 1 A g 1 accompanied with remarkable rate performance of 66.1% capacity retention (395.5/598.5) in a threeelectrode system. When assembling asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC) devices using Co3O4 thin sheets (Co3O4 thin sheets/Ni foam) as positive electrode and active carbon (AC/Ni foam) as negative electrode, the energy density of the ASC device can be as high as 22.49Wh$kg 1 at the power density of 800Wkg 1 with only 8.2% loss of its initial specific capacity value at 10 A g 1 over 10000 cycles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials preparation
sections.text: All the reagents were of analytical purity grade with no further purification and double-distilled water (DDW) was used throughout the experimental. The synthetic process of the porous Co3O4 thin sheets is schematically shown in Scheme 1. Typically, 3mmol Co(NO3)2$6H2O were dissolved in 40mL DDW under magnetic stirring to form a homogeneous Solution I. Then 6mmol BA was added into 40ml DDW at 60 C under stirring to obtain Solution II. Subsequently, Solution I was dropped into solution II under stirring at 60 C and kept stirring for 6 h to form Solution III. Finally, the resulting Solution III was transferred into a 100mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave maintained at 200 C for different reaction time of 6, 12 and 24 h under a heating rate of 5 C$min 1 and the corresponding products were named as S-1, S-2 and S-3, respectively. After cooling down to room temperature naturally, all the products were taken out and washed with DDW and ethanol for three times, and subsequently dried in vacuum at 80 C for 6 h.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material characterizations
sections.text: A Bruker D8 Advance powder Xeray diffract meter (XRD) was employed to characterize the crystal structure of the material. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were conducted on a specific surface area and mesoporous/microporous analyzer (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020) at 77.350 K to acquire the surface property of the as-prepared sample. The size and shape of the products were detected by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (HITACHI S-4800 electron microscopy) with energydispersive Xeray (EDX) spectra at 20 kV and Tecnai G2 F20 STwin transmission electron microscopy (TEM) at 200 kV.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The electrochemical performance of the samples was carried out on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation in 6.0M KOH
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of the synthesis of the Co3O4 thin sheets by direct hydrothermal decomposition of the mixed aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2) and benzoic acid (C6H5COOH) with digital photos of the samples in a beaker and after drying.
solution at room temperature in a conventional three-electrode system. The working electrodes were prepared by mixing 80:10:10wt % of synthesized Co3O4, acetylene black and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) with N-methyl 2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) as solvent to form a slurry, which was then coated on one cleaned nickel foam sheet (1 cm 2 cm). In addition, the counter electrode and reference electrode of the system were a Platinum sheet and a standard calomel electrode (SCE), respectively. Furthermore, the frequency ranges from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz during electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis. The cycling performance of the synthesized sample was examined on a LANHE battery test equipment (Wuhan LAND Co., Ltd).

sections.heading: 2.4. ASC assembly and measurements
sections.text: As shown schematically in Scheme 2, the ASC devices were assembled using the as-prepared Co3O4 thin sheets (Co3O4/Ni foam) as the positive electrode, AC (AC/Ni foam) as the negative electrode, cellulose paper as the separator and 6M KOH as the electrolyte. Ensuring charge balance is essential to assemble an ASC device, so we optimized the mass ratio of the Co3O4 thin sheets and AC with the formula:, wherem (g) refers tomþ =m ¼ ðC DV Þ= ðCþ DVþÞ the mass loading of active material, V is the potential window of the electrode and C represents the specific capacitance of the electrodematerial. The optimizedmass ratios of S1/AC, S2/AC and S3/AC were calculated to be 0.79, 0.65 and 0.98, respectively. The preparation of the negative electrode was the same as that of the positive electrode except using AC as the active material.

sections.heading: 3.1. Structure and composition analysis
sections.text:
To analyze the crystalline structure and phase information of the samples, XRD patterns of S-1, S-2 and S-3 were investigated with the corresponding results in Fig. 1a. Typical reflection planes of (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) appeared in the three XRD patterns, which matches well with standard data of
Co3O4 (JCPDS No. 014-0688). No other sharp peaks can be observed, confirming pure Co3O4 were successfully prepared. The EDX spectra were further employed to analyze the element composition of the three samples. As shown in Fig. 1b, there exhibit obvious peaks of Co, O and Au, inwhich the additional Au signal was derived from the sprinkled Au during SEM test. And the ratio between Co and O is estimated to be about 3:4, confirming the samples are pure Co3O4. In all, pure Co3O4 were obtained via direct hydrothermal decomposition of the mixed aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate and BA.

sections.heading: 3.2. Surface and porosity analyses
sections.text:
The Brunauere-Emmette-Teller (BET) surface area and pore size distribution are the basic and necessary parameters for SCs electrode materials, which play an important role in determine their electrochemical performance. N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted to investigate the surface property of the assynthesized three samples. Fig. 1ced shows the N2 adsorptionedesorption isotherms and pore size distributions of S1, S-2 and S-3. All the adsorptionedesorption isotherms of three samples display typical IV-type isothermwith a H2-type hysteresis loop, which indicates the characteristic of mesoporous in the samples [64]. As inset in Fig.1d, the BET surface areas of S-1, S-2 and S-3 were calculated to be 69.96, 142.15 and 42.07m2 g 1 with cumulative pore volumes of 0.25 0.27 and 0.18 cm3 g 1, respectively. By Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) analyses, the average pore sizes are 7.78, 6.09 and 10.38 nm for S1, S2 and S3. According to the BET result, S-2 possess much larger BET surface area than S-1 and S-3. The formation process of Co3O4 porous sheets during hydrothermal process may includes three steps of (ⅰ) dissolution, (ⅱ) nucleation and (ⅲ) growth. During which, a few nanosheets can be formed on the surface of the thin sheets in too short reaction time, which results in lower specific surface area of the sample; too many nanosheets may appeared on the thin sheets during too long reaction time and the corresponding specific surface area becomes smaller due to the superposition and interlacing of nanosheets on the thin sheets. The porous structure with high BET specific surface
area is able to provide larger surface area with more electro-active sites and efficient transport for electrons and ions, thus improving the charge storage performance of the sample.

sections.heading: 3.3. Size and morphology analysis
sections.text:
The detailed structural feature of the samples was further inspected by SEM and TEM. Fig. 2 depicts the SEM images of S-2 at
different magnifications. From Fig. 2a that under low resolution, the sample displayed a 2D thin sheet-like structure with smooth surface and width of about tens to hundreds of micrometers, which is well corresponded to the digital photos of S-2 prepared under 200 C for 12 h in Scheme 1. Afterwards, the high resolution SEM images in Fig. 2ced further show that the 2D thin sheet-like structure is consist of plenty of stacked nanoflakes. These nanoflakes are interconnectedwith each other and thereby assembling a 3D nanoflake array network with plenty of intricate pores and large surface area, which not only offer efficient access for charge transfer and more electro-active sites but also promote the penetration of electrolyte. As a comparison, the SEM images under different magnifications of S1 (under 200 C for 6 h) and S3 (under 200 C for 24 h) are also given in Fig. 2eeh and Fig. 2iel, respectively. From the low-resolution SEM image in Fig. 2eef, it's clear that S-2 is consisting of numerous thin sheets with interlaced fold-like nanoflakes on the surface. Furthermore, the high-resolution images of S-1 in Fig. 2geh demonstrate that these nanoflakes are growing from the surface of the sample to form a porous structure. Moreover, the SEM images of S3 are displayed in Fig. 2iel, S-3 exhibits thin sheetlike structure with obvious cavities under low resolution in Fig. 2iej. From the high resolution SEM images in Fig. 2kel, S-3 displays network-like structure composed of large-scale vertically aligned nanoflakes. These interconnected nanoflakes are tightly stacked together and form lots of cavities with diameter of about hundreds of nanometers.
Furthermore, TEM images of S-1, S-2 and S-3 are characterized in Fig. 3aec, respectively. From low-resolution TEM images in Fig. 3aec, the samples display fan-shaped thin sheet-like structure with large scale of wrinkles and diffused nanosheets whose width are tens to hundreds of nanometers. Moreover, S-2 in Fig. 3b possesses smooth and flat surface, which is in good agreement with the SEM image in Fig. 2a. Additionally, Fig. 3def depict the HR-TEM images of S-1, S-2 and S-3, respectively, from the inset of the figures we can find the lattice spacing of three samples was 0.24 nm. The lattice distance can be well corresponded to the (311) facet of crystallized Co3O4, corresponding to the results of XRD and EDX.

sections.heading: 3.4. Electrochemical behavior of the three samples
sections.text:
To investigate the electrochemical performance of the assynthesized porous Co3O4 thin sheets as electrode materials for SCs, cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) and EISmeasurements were carried out in a three-electrode system in 6M KOH aqueous electrolyte at room temperature. Fig. 4aec shows the CV curves at different scan rates from 10 to 100mV s 1 in the potential range of 0e0.5 V (vs. SCE). All the CV curves display two typical asymmetric redox peaks of oxidation and reduction, which are different from those of electrical double layer capacitors (EDLCs) with a quasi-rectangular shape, revealing a typical a battery-type electrode characteristic of faradaic redox reactions due to the Co3O4/CoOOH/CoO2 transformation [65]. As the scan rate increases, the shape of CV curves keep almost no change and still displays distinctive redox peaks at high scan rate, but the position of the peaks changed with the anodic peak moves positively and cathodic one shifts negatively, which could be attributed to the fact that ion diffusion is the step of rate limiting. The diffusion rate of the ions on the interface of active material/electrolyte at high scan rate was too fast, so lots of ions gathered and left on the surface of the electrodes in a very short time, leading to inadequate redox reactions and concentration polarization. Even at a high scan rate of 100mV s 1, the CV curve still keeps obvious redox peaks, which suggests a good rate of the electrochemical performance of the Co3O4 thin sheet-based electrodes. Furthermore, from Fig. 4aec of the linear relationship of the values of the peak currents (i) and the square root of the scan rate (n0:5), it indicates fast redox reactions and battery-type behavior of the Co3O4 thin sheet-based electrode with a diffusion-control process [66]. The specific capacities (Qs, C$g 1) of the as-prepared samples from the CV curves at different scan rates were calculated based on the following equation: QSC;m;CV ¼ ð R vt v0 IðVÞdVÞ=ð2mvÞ, where I (A) represents the current, Vt and V0 (V) refers to the highest and lowest output potential difference of the CV curves, v (mV$s 1) and m (g) correspond to the scan rate and loading mass of the electrode material, respectively. Fig. S1a displays the CV profiles of S-1, S-2 and S-3 at a scan rate of
60mV s 1 with calculated specific capacity results shown in Fig. S1b. The specific capacities of S2 was 380 C g 1, larger than that of S1 with 340 C g 1 and S3 with 305 C g 1, which is well corresponding to the CV curves.
Furthermore, GCD curves of S-1, S-2 and S-3-based electrodes at different current densities from 1 to 10 A g 1 are presented in Fig. 5aec. All of them exhibit two distinct charge-discharge potential flats in each curve, which are different from EDLC-type curves with favorable linearity and symmetry, indicating a typical battery-type behavior from prominent redox reaction, which are well consistent with the CV results. The corresponding specific capacities (Qsc,m,GCD, C$g 1) from GCD curves under various current densities could be acquired by the following equation: QSC;m;GCD ¼
ðI$DtÞ=m, where I (A) represents the discharge current, Dt (s) refers to the discharge time and m (g) corresponds to the loading mass of the electrode material. Fig. 5d shows the GCD curves of S-1, S-2 and S-3-based electrodes at a current density of 1 A g 1 and the corresponding specific capacities in Fig. 5e are 497, 598.5 and 399 C g 1. Among which, the S-2-based electrode displayed a higher specific capacity of 598.5 C g 1 at a current density of 1 A g 1 in Fig. 5f, which is higher than most of the previously reported 1D, 2D or 3D Co3O4 nanostructures for SCs in Table 1 [67e82]. The high specific capacity of the as-synthesized Co3O4 thin sheets can be ascribed to their high surface area, 2D mesoporous structure and ultrathin nanosheets assembled 3D hierarchical micro-/nano-structures. And the specific capacity of S-2-based electrode can still remain

66.1% (395.5/598.5) of its initial value even at a high current density of 10 A g 1, suggesting a relatively good rate capability. In order to exclude the influence of nickel foam on the 2D porous Co3O4 thin sheet-based electrodes during electrochemical tests, the electrochemical behaviors including CV and GCD curves of bare Ni foam were also measured for comparison. The CV curve of the bare Ni foam has a very weak current response and a considerably small integral area. Moreover, it shows only an extremely short duration time in GCD curve. Therefore, the capacity contribution from the Ni foam can be negligible in contrast with that of the Co3O4 thin sheets.
The cycling performance of S-1, S-2 and S-3-based electrodes were further investigated by GCD tests at a current density of
10 A g 1 for 8000 cycles. As shown in Fig. 6a, all three samples display good cyclic stability of about only 9.8, 6.3 and 13.1% loss of specific capacity after 8000 cycles, which is better than reported Co3O4 nanostructures in Table 1, indicating the charge/discharge process is substantially reversible, the materials architecture are fairly steady, and the pore accessibility for electrolyte ions are highly stable upon long-term cycling tests. These electrochemical results indicate that the synthesized porous Co3O4 thin sheets could be a promising candidate as electrode materials for the application in high-performance SCs.
The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is studied in Fig. 6b, which reveals the Nyquist plots for S-1, S-2 and S-3 with an equivalent circuit in the inset of Fig. 6b. Considering the existence
of inhomogeneous reaction rates and roughness on the surface of the electrode, the constant phase element (CPE) is used to compensate the dispersion effect [83e85]. The Nyquist plots exhibit a small semicircle under high frequency and a straight line in the low-frequency region which are attributed to diffusive resistance (Warburg impedance, W) and the charge-transfer process in the interface between electrode and electrolyte, respectively. The high-frequency intercept of the semicircle with the real axis represents the equivalent series resistance (Rs), and the diameter of the semicircle refers to Faradaic charge-transfer resistance (Rct) [86,87]. The fitting impedance parameters are displayed in Table 2, fromwhich we can observe that Rs of S-1, S-2 and S-3 are 0.5138, 0.3709 and 0.5209U while Rct are 0.05101, 0.02624 and 0.80580U, respectively, and it's very clear that Rs and Rct of S-2 are lower than that of S-1 and S-3, indicating better conductivity of the S-2-based electrode and smaller interfacial charge transfer resistance. These results all demonstrate S-2 possess superior electrochemical performance than S-1 and S-3.

sections.heading: 3.5. Electrochemical behavior of the ASC device
sections.text:
Due to low specific capacitance ( 150 F g 1) and output potential difference ( 2.7 V), the energy density of the AC-based SCs is low (6Wh$kg 1), which limits their large-scale applications in electric vehicles, hybrid electric vehicles and other fields. Therefore, it is urgent to increase the specific capacity and working output potential difference of SCs, so as to maximize their energy density. Since the Co3O4 thin sheets possess excellent electrochemical performance, which is able to meet the requirements of future practical application of energy storage device. Firstly, the CV curves of AC, S-1, S-2 and S-3 at the scan rate of 60mV s 1 are put together in Fig. 7a where AC showed a typical EDLC feature in the working potential window of 1.0-0 V while Co3O4 thin sheets exhibited battery-type behavior with strong redox peaks in the working potential window of 0e0.5 V, manifesting the feasibility of these two electrodes to assemble an ASC device. Fig. 7b depicts the CV curves of S-1//AC, S-2//AC and S-3//AC devices at 60mV s 1. Unlike the rectangular shape for EDLC-type behavior and asymmetrical
curves with distinct redox peaks of battery-type behavior, all CV curves display a particular shape, combining high energy redox of the Co3O4 thin sheets and high power EDLC of AC. The CV curves of S-2//AC device possess a larger area than S-1//AC and S-3//AC devices, suggesting a higher specific capacity. The mass specific capacity (QASC,M, C$g 1) and mass specific capacitance (CASC,M, F$g 1) of the ASC device were calculated using the following equations: QASC;M ¼ ðI$DtÞ=M and CASC;M ¼ ðI$DtÞ=ðM$DVÞ, respectively, in which I (A) represents the discharge current, Dt (s) is the discharge time, DV (V) refers to the potential range, M (g) stands for the total weight of the ASC device, respectively. The calculated specific capacities given in Fig. 7c are 55.46, 67.65 and 52.02 C g 1, respectively, which confirm the preceding result. To find a rational cell output potential difference, the CV curves of the S-2//AC ASC device with various working output potential difference at 50mV s 1 were displayed in Fig. 8a. And it's worth noting that polarization of the electrode didn't take place till the output potential difference was extended to 0e1.8 V, and no polarization occurs before 0e1.6 V. So 0e1.6 V was chosen to be the rational output potential difference to ensure the security and stability of the device. Fig. 8b shows the CV curves of the S-2//AC ASC device under various scan rates, and the ASC device still display both EDLC-type and battery-type behavior even at 100mV s 1, indicating successful fabrication of the ASC device. Fig. 8c represents the GCD curves of the S-2//AC ASC device in the potential range of 0e1.6 V at various current densities of 0.5e10 A g 1. And it can clearly be seen that the curves are almost symmetrical, suggesting the well linearity of discharge/charge output potential difference versus time and high coulomb efficiency. The corresponding discharge specific capacitances are displayed in Fig. 8d, which achieve a highest specific capacity of 143.41 C g 1 at the current density of 0.5 A g 1. The GCD curves and calculated specific capacity of S-1//AC and S-3//AC devices were shown in Fig. S2. The highest specific capacities of S-1//AC and S-3// AC devices can reach 60.66 and 48.65C g 1 at a current density of 1 A g 1, which are both smaller than that of S-2//AC device. In addition, cyclic performance is still vital for the actual application of ASC devices. Thus, the cyclic performance of the S-2//AC ASC device is shown in Fig. 8e, which exhibits an outstanding cyclic stability with 8.2% loss over 10000 cycles under a high current density of 10 A g 1.
The most fatal factors for judging the performance of an ASC device are power density and energy density. The energy density (E, Wh$kg 1), and power density (P, W$kg 1) of the ASC device were calculated using the following equations: E ¼ ½CASC;MðDV2Þ =7:2 and P ¼ ð3600 EÞ=Dt, respectively. The Ragone plot of S-2//AC ASC device is shown in Fig. 8f, the calculated energy density of the S-2//AC ASC device decreases from 22.49 to 6Wh$kg 1 with the
power density increasing from 800 to 8000Wkg 1, which is superior to S-1//AC (13.78Wh$kg 1 at 800Wkg 1), S-3//AC (10.58Wh$kg 1 at 800Wkg 1) and many reported ASC devices, such as Hierarchical Co3O4 hollow nanocubes//AC (21.8Wh$kg 1 at 400Wkg 1) [88], Co3O4 nanowires//AC (24.9Wh$kg 1 at 225Wkg 1) [89], Co3O4 nanowires//CA microspheres (17.9Wh$kg 1 at 750Wkg 1) [90], Co3O4 nanoparticles//rGO (13.51Wh$kg 1 at 844Wkg 1) [91], Co3O4 nanowires//Co3O4 nanowires (6.7Wh$kg 1 at 248.65Wkg 1) [92], Co3O4 hollow tube network//AC (29.5Wh$kg 1 at 104Wkg 1) [93] and Co3O4 nanosheets//AC (15.4Wh$kg 1 at 800Wkg 1) [56]. All in all, these outstanding electrochemical performance of the Co3O4 thin sheets can make it a promising candidate for high-performance ASC applications.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, ultrathin nanosheets assembled two-dimensional porous Co3O4 thin sheets with 3D hierarchical micro-/nano-structures have been successfully synthesized via direct hydrothermal decomposition of aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate in the presence of BA. The obtained porous Co3O4 thin sheets exhibit excellent electrochemical performance as battery-type materials for SCs. In a
three-electrode system, the specific capacity of the Co3O4 thin sheets can reach a maximum value of 598.5 C g 1 at a current density of 1 A g 1 with an outstanding cyclic stability of 93.7% capacity retention. The ASC device that combining the high specific capacity of single electrode and the extended working output potential difference derived from asymmetric electrodes can get a wider working output potential difference of 0e1.6 V and a high energy density of 22.49Wh$kg 1 at the power density of 800Wkg 1. These results in this work could be expanded to rational design and future development of 2D transition metal based nanomaterials for applications in high-performance supercapacitors.

metadata.abstractText: Two-dimensional (2D) porous materials have been proved to be meritorious for supercapacitors (SCs) due to unique properties of large surface area, superior intrinsic porosity and high electrical conductivity. In this work, we reported for the first synthesis of 2D porous Co3O4 thin sheets assembled by ultrathin nanosheets via direct hydrothermal decomposition of aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate in the presence of benzoic acid (BA) without any template or surfactant. High specific capacity (497, 598.5 and 399 C g 1 at 1.0 A g 1) and remarkable cycling stability (9.8, 6.3 and 13.1% loss over 8000 cycles at 10.0 A g 1) were achieved in a three-electrode system for the Co3O4 thin sheets at 200 C for 6, 12 and 24 h with different specific surface area of 69.96, 142.15 and 42.07m2 g 1, which can be attributed to the special structural feature of an open and porous surface layer and the synergistic effect of 2D and 3D structure that significantly facilitates fast electron transport, ion diffusion and intimate electrode/electrolyte contact. Furthermore, an assembled asymmetric supercapacitor (ASC, Co3O4 thin sheets//activated carbon (AC)) can reach a working output potential difference of 0e1.6 V with a maximum energy density of 22.49Wh$kg 1 at the power density of 800Wkg 1 with excellent cyclic stability (only 8.2% loss of its initial specific capacity value over 10000 cycles). The results show that our synthesis provides a new insight into the fabrication of 2D hierarchical porous Co3O4 thin sheets; in addition, the as-synthesized Co3O4 thin sheets have potential for various applications in SCs, electrochemical sensing, and lithium ion battery. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
